books.title: Martin Amis: An Appreciation
books.description: Martin Amis in 2007.

books.title: Book Review: ‘NB by J.C.,’ by James Campbell
books.description: “NB by J.C.” collects the variegated musings of James Campbell in the Times Literary Supplement.

books.title: In ‘Fires in the Dark,’ Kay Redfield Jamison Turns to Healers
books.description: When Kay Redfield Jamison started to write about her own experiences with mental illness, she met people who felt her writing had changed their lives. She also received a lot of rejection.

books.title: The Detective Novel ‘Whose Body?,’ by Dorothy L. Sayers, Turns 100
books.description: Dorothy L. Sayers at the Detection Club, a society of crime writers that she helped establish.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Dom Casmurro,’ by Machado de Assis
books.description: “Dom Casmurro,” by Machado de Assis, teaches us to read — and reread — with precise detail and masterly obfuscation.

books.title: Book Review: ‘The Late Americans,’ by Brandon Taylor
books.description: Brandon Taylor’s novel circulates among Iowa City residents, some privileged, some not, but all aware that their possibilities are contracting.

books.title: Martin Amis’s Best Books: A Guide
books.description: Martin Amis in 2012 at his home in Brooklyn. He published 15 novels, which drew acclaim for their wit and linguistic ingenuity.

books.title: The Best Romance Novels of 2024 (So Far)
books.description: Looking for an escapist love story? Here are 2024’s sexiest, swooniest reads.

books.title: What Book Should You Read Next?
books.description: Finding a book you’ll love can be daunting. Let us help.

books.title: Book Review: ‘The Silk Road,’ by Christopher Wilton-Steer
books.description: A new book of photographs captures the landscapes, buildings and faces along the route that once conveyed untold wealth between Europe and China.

books.title: the Writer-Director Larry Charles Tells Tales of Working on ‘Borat’ and ‘Curb’
books.description: “I’ve always been attracted to the transgressive,” says Larry Charles, the author of “Comedy Samurai.”

books.title: Best Books About Witches
books.description: The fantasy author Charlie Jane Anders recommends some of her favorite, most magical books.

books.title: Book Review: ‘I’ll Be Right Here,’ by Amy Bloom
books.description: Two of the historical figures who play parts in Amy Bloom’s new novel are, from left, the writer Colette (circa 1905) and the jewelry designer Suzanne Belperron (in 1933).

books.title: Book Review: “Graciela in the Abyss,” by Meg Medina, and “Blood in the Water,” by Tiffany D. Jackson
books.description: Visit the aquatic hereafter in a fantasy, then track down threats on Martha’s Vineyard in a taut contemporary suspense novel.

books.title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
books.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

books.title: Book Review: ‘The Palm-Wine Drinkard,’ by Amos Tutuola
books.description: With folk traditions and sui generis prose, Amos Tutuola enthralled readers with his magic realist novel “The Palm-Wine Drinkard.”

books.title: Best Fake Dating Romance Books, According to Jasmine Guillory
books.description: Feigned love leads to real connections in these funny, joyful and deeply romantic books.

books.title: Interview: Stephen Fry on Greek Mythology and His Favorite Books
books.description: “I try to fight this lamentable tendency,” he says, but now reads more nonfiction than fiction. “Odyssey” is the fourth in his series on Greek mythology.

books.title: Vicki Goldberg Dies at 88; Saw Photography Through a Literary Lens
books.description: An influential photography critic, she wrote essays, newspaper columns and books, including a notable biography of the photojournalist Margaret Bourke-White.

books.title: A Teenage Soldier’s Wartime Scrapbook Inspired His Granddaughter’s First Novel
books.description: “I wanted to see what happens in the space where biography and fiction collide,” Heather Clark said of the decision to write “The Scrapbook,” her first novel.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Claire McCardell,’ by Elizabeth Evitts Dickinson
books.description: Claire McCardell, pictured here in 1940, had a quietly revolutionary ethos: Women’s clothes can be practical, comfortable, stylish and affordable. And have pockets.

books.title: Book Review: ‘The Uproar’ by Karim Dimechkie
books.description: In Karim Dimechkie’s “The Uproar,” the best-laid plans meet worst-case scenarios again and again.

books.title: Jonas Hassen Khemiri Discusses ‘The Sisters’
books.description: For the first time, Jonas Hassen Khemiri wrote a novel in English and translated it into Swedish.

books.title: Walter Brueggemann, Theologian Who Argued for the Poor, Dies at 92
books.description: He used biblical exegesis to argue that faith demands justice, calling on churches to challenge oppression and uplift society’s marginalized.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Not My Type,’ by E. Jean Carroll
books.description: E. Jean Carroll’s “Not My Type” is both a memoir and a scrapbook of the two trials in which she accused President Trump of sexual assault and defamation.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Toni at Random: The Iconic Writer’s Legendary Editorship,’ by Dana A. Williams
books.description: In her new book, “Toni at Random,” Dana A. Williams highlights the groundbreaking writer’s time working in publishing.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Fox,’ by Joyce Carol Oates
books.description: “Fox” details the devastation wrought by a manipulative English teacher who sexually abuses his students.

books.title: Book Review: ‘The Scrapbook,’ by Heather Clark
books.description: In Heather Clark’s novel, “The Scrapbook,” an American girl meets a German boy and falls head over heels — and headfirst into a history of fascism.

books.title: William Langewiesche, the ‘Steve McQueen of Journalism,’ Dies at 70
books.description: William Langewiesche in 2002. For a decade, his articles were routinely finalists for the National Magazine Award, two of which won the prize.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Bug Hollow,’ by Michelle Huneven
books.description: Michelle Huneven’s novel “Bug Hollow” begins with a tragedy in 1970s California. The ramifications are felt across three countries and five decades.

books.title: Book Review: ‘Fake Work,’ by Leigh Claire La Berge
books.description: Leigh Claire La Berge’s memoir looks back at her stint as a consultant for a Fortune 500 company at the turn of the millennium: “Is this how companies are put together?”

books.title: Book Review: ‘Tramps Like Us,” by Joe Westmoreland
books.description: Joe Westmoreland captures the pleasures and pains of American wanderlust in his forgotten classic “Tramps Like Us.”

books.title: A.I. Is Poised to Rewrite History. Literally.
books.description: The technology’s ability to read and summarize text is already making it a useful tool for scholarship. How will it change the stories we tell about the past?

books.title: Book Review: ‘How to Dodge a Cannonball,’ by Dennard Dayle
books.description: Dennard Dayle’s satirical new book, “How to Dodge a Cannonball,” follows a white flag-bearer pretending to be a Black soldier.

books.title: Norma Swenson, ‘Our Bodies, Ourselves’ Co-Author, Dies at 93
books.description: She was a proponent of natural childbirth when she joined the group that produced a candid guide to women’s health. It became a cultural touchstone and a global best seller.

books.title: Book Review: “The Möbius Book, by Catherine Lacey
books.description: Catherine Lacey’s “The Möbius Book” is both an elliptical novella and a seething memoir. Decoding the connections is at once frustrating and exhilarating.

books.title: Molly Recommends 2 Very Male New Novels
books.description: Johann Joachim Winckelmann and book

books.title: Book Review: ‘Endling,’ by Maria Reva
books.description: That is, until war breaks out. “Endling,” by Maria Reva, is an ambitious whirlwind of a novel, set in Ukraine on the brink of disaster.

books.title: Trying to Sell a Conservative Book? Go on a Podcast.
books.description: Many of the most popular shows welcome right-wing arguments and freewheeling conversation. Publishers of other political stripes are noticing, too.

books.title: Book Review: ‘What Is Queer Food?’ by John Birdsall and ‘Dining Out,’ by Erik Piepenburg
books.description: The late, lamented Chelsea diner Florent was a mainstay of the gay dining scene for more than 20 years.

books.title: Marthe Cohn, a Wartime Jewish Nurse Who Spied for the French, Dies at 105
books.description: Fluent in German and passing as an Aryan, she once crossed into Germany, uncovered Nazi military secrets and nursed a wounded, and deceived, SS officer.

books.title: E. Jean Carroll Chronicles Her Legal Battles With Trump in a New Book
books.description: E. Jean Carroll, at right, after a 2024 appeals court hearing on the verdict in her favor in a sexual assault and defamation case against President Trump.

books.title: 50 Years After ‘Jaws’ Terrified Filmgoers, a Reporter Looks Back
books.description: The culture critic Brian Raftery, who wrote about “Jaws” for the Book Review last year, discusses the movie’s anniversary with Gilbert Cruz.
